title: 115_hr1758
content: The "Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2017" increases funding limits for direct remediation and introduces multipurpose Brownfields grants. The "Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2017" introduces multipurpose brownfields grants under Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. The "Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2017" introduces grants for characterization, assessment, planning, or remediation activities at brownfield sites. Grant amounts are capped at $950,000 per grant and 15% of funds for the fiscal year. Criteria for awarding grants include the ability to provide an overall plan. The Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2017 introduces grants for revitalization of brownfield sites, requiring eligible entities to demonstrate capacity and meet site needs. Grants must be fully expended within 3 years of receiving them. The Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2017 requires eligible entities to fully expend grants within 3 years unless an extension is granted by the Administrator. SEC. 4. EXPANDED ELIGIBILITY FOR NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. Section 104(k)(1) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include eligibility criteria for nonprofit organizations, limited liability corporations, and limited partnerships. The eligibility criteria for nonprofit organizations, limited liability corporations, and limited partnerships under Section 104(k)(1) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 include specific requirements such as having all general partners as qualified organizations or limited liability corporations with sole members being qualified organizations, or being a qualified community development entity as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. Allowing administrative costs for grant recipients. SEC. 5. Allowing administrative costs for grant recipients. Paragraph (5) of section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions regarding administrative costs for eligible entities. An eligible entity can use up to 9 percent of grant or loan funds for administrative costs, excluding costs related to contamination investigation, response action design, and natural resource monitoring. SEC. 6. Treatment of certain publicly owned brownfield sites: An eligible governmental entity may receive a grant for property acquired before January 11, 2002, even if it does not qualify as a bona fide prospective purchaser, as long as it has not caused or contributed to a hazardous substance release. SEC. 7 amends the authorization of appropriations for the Comprehensive Environmental Response Act to allocate $250,000,000 annually from 2017 to 2022. SEC. 8 adjusts the State Response Program funding timeline to 2022.
